subject: Leadership
title: Learning from Scandals
description: A fast breakdown of Learning from Scandals for builders.

hook.text: Enron, Theranos, Volkswagen. Each scandal seemed unique. But the patterns underneath repeat with eerie consistency.

buildup.text: Common factors: unchecked authority, pressure to perform, weak oversight, and a culture that punished dissent.

discovery.text: Palmer's institutional theory: organizations create conditions where normal people do abnormal things through pressure.

twist.text: We blame individual bad actors. But the system that created them often survives intact and creates the next scandal.

climax.text: After every scandal, fix the system, not just the person. Strengthen oversight, reduce pressure, and protect dissenters.

punchline.text: The scandal you don't study is the one you'll repeat.

quiz.question: What common factor links most corporate scandals?
options: They are caused by a single bad individual
Systemic conditions like unchecked authority and pressure to perform
They happen randomly with no pattern
